name: Ugali
description: A staple Kenyan dish made from maize flour cooked in boiling water to a stiff porridge-like consistency.
instructions: Bring water to a boil in a heavy-bottomed pot.
Gradually add the maize flour to the boiling water, stirring continuously with a wooden spoon to avoid lumps.
Continue stirring and pressing out any lumps until the mixture thickens and pulls away from the sides of the pot, forming a firm dough.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and let it cook for another 5-10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot with stews, vegetables (sukuma wiki), or grilled meat (nyama choma).

name: Sukuma Wiki
description: A common Kenyan side dish made from collard greens (sukuma wiki) cooked with onions, tomatoes, and spices.
instructions: Heat vegetable oil in a pot or pan over medium heat.
Add chopped onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in minced garlic and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add diced tomatoes and cook until they break down and form a sauce, about 8-10 minutes.
Add the chopped sukuma wiki to the pot and stir well to combine.
Season with cumin powder and salt to taste.
Cover and simmer for 10-15 minutes, or until the sukuma wiki is tender.
Serve hot as a side dish with ugali or other main meals.

name: Githeri
description: A traditional Kenyan one-pot dish made from a mixture of maize (corn) and beans, often with vegetables.
instructions: Drain and rinse the soaked maize and beans.

In a large pot, combine the maize and beans with enough water to cover them. Bring to a boil and then simmer until they are tender, about 1-2 hours (cooking time may vary depending on the type of beans and maize). Add more water if needed during cooking.
In a separate pan, heat vegetable oil over medium heat.
Add chopped onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Stir in diced tomatoes and cook until they break down, about 8 minutes.
Add the cooked maize and beans to the tomato mixture. If using, add diced potatoes and carrots.
Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
Simmer for another 15-20 minutes to allow the flavors to meld together and the vegetables (if added) to cook through.
Serve hot as a hearty main dish.

name: Nyama Choma
description: Grilled meat (typically goat or beef) that is a popular dish in Kenya.
instructions: Prepare your grill (charcoal or gas) to medium-high heat.
Season the meat pieces generously with salt and black pepper (if using).
Grill the meat, turning occasionally, until it is cooked through and has a nice char. Cooking time will vary depending on the thickness of the meat and your desired level of doneness.
For goat meat, ensure it is cooked thoroughly.
Serve hot with kachumbari (tomato and onion salad) and ugali. Offer lemon or lime wedges for squeezing over the meat.

name: Mandazi
description: A slightly sweet fried bread that is a popular snack or breakfast item in Kenya.
instructions: In a large bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and cardamom powder (if using).
In a separate bowl, combine milk, water, and vegetable oil.
Gradually add the wet ingredients to the dry ingredients, mixing until a soft dough forms.
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 5-7 minutes until smooth.
Divide the dough into 12 equal pieces. Roll each piece into a ball and then flatten it slightly into a round or triangular shape.
Heat vegetable oil in a deep fryer or large pan over medium heat (about 350°F or 175°C).
Carefully add the mandazi to the hot oil, working in batches if necessary, and fry for 2-3 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Remove the mandazi with a slotted spoon and place them on a paper towel-lined plate to drain excess oil.
Serve warm, dusted with powdered sugar if desired, as a snack or for breakfast with tea or coffee.
